content: Street food stall in Singapore **Warong Nasi Pariaman** is an eatery along [North Bridge Road](/wiki/North_Bridge_Road) and Kandahar Street in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). The restaurant is believed to be the oldest surviving stall selling [Nasi Padang](/wiki/Nasi_Padang) in Singapore. ## History The eatery was founded in 1948 by Haji Isrin from [Pariaman](/wiki/Pariaman) at the corner of North Bridge Road and Kandahar Street. After Haji retired, the business went to his wife, Hajah Rosnah. In 1988, the business went to their sons Sudirman, Jumrin and Abdul, and their wives. However, Sudirman, who had been heading the team, later left. In 2021, the [National Heritage Board](/wiki/National_Heritage_Board_(Singapore)) designated the eatery as a "mini-museum". This was done in an effort to raise awareness to smaller business with a long history and were often overlooked. ## Reception Anette Tan of the *[Cond√© Nast Traveler](/wiki/Cond%C3%A9_Nast_Traveler)* included the restaurant in her list of the 28 Best Restaurants in Singapore in 2019. In 2016, it was awarded the Heritage Heroes Award for preserving local culinary traditions. This [Singaporean cuisine](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine)-related article is a stub. title: Warong Nasi Pariaman
